tutorial.title: Profile Information Form
tutorial.descriptionContent: Create a form for updating users' social media profile information using HTML

executableContent.instructions:
For this project, we'll create an HTML form that social media users can use to update their profiles.

We've already added the following code to help you get started.

1. In `index.html` file, the basic HTML tags are added, with a `link` attribute that links to the CSS file.
2. In `style.css` file, CSS styles for the HTML elements are added. For now, you don't have to worry about styling. We'll learn the same in the later chapters.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" />
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Let's start with the headings. Headings are important to convey essential information about a site, like the name of the site, brief descriptions of the site, additional information etc.

In this page, we'll use one heading that tells the name of the site and a sub heading that gives a brief description of the form that we're creating.

1. Create an `h1` element that says `friendsbook.`.
2. Create an `h3` element below the `h1` element that says `Update Profile Information`.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" />
  </head>
  <body>
  </body>
</html>

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. Use `

` to create an `h1` element. 2. Use `

` to create an `h3` element.

executableContent.instructions:
Now that we have the headings set, let's start with the form to allow social media users to update their profile information.

To create a form, we need to use the `form` element, which will create a form structure.

1. Create a `form` element below the `h3` element.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Use `<form></form>` to create a form element.

executableContent.instructions:
We'll divide our form into three sections - *Personal Info*, *Update Password*, and *More about you*.

For each section, we'll use `fieldset` element to group related inputs together, making it more organized.

1. Create an element inside the `form` element that groups related inputs together.
2. Create a `legend` element inside the `fieldset` element that says `Personal Info`.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information
files.solvedContent:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
Remember you can use `<fieldset></fieldset>` to create a `fieldset` element to group related inputs together
Use `<legend></legend>` to create a `legend` element.

executableContent.instructions:
Our first `fieldset` is ready. Time to add some inputs like name, birthday etc.!

The first information that we'll take from the user is their name. So let's add a label and an input.

1. Below the `legend`, create a `label` element that says `Name: `. Set the `for` attribute of this element to `name`.
2. After that, create an input for the user to add text. Set its `id` attribute to `name`.
3. Add a line break.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info
files.solvedContent:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. To assign an attribute, use `attributeName = value`. 2. For line break, use `
`. 3. `input` element has no closing tag. 4. Make sure that the `for` attribute of a label and the `id` attribute of the corresponding input are the same.

executableContent.instructions:
Great! Let's add the remaining labels and inputs.

We've already asked for the user's name. Now, we'll ask for their email and birthday. This will sum up the `Personal Info` section of the form.

1. Below the name `input`, create another `label` element that says `Email: `. Set the `for` attribute of this element to `email`.
2. After that, create an input for the user to add email. Set its `id` attribute to `email`.
3. Add a line break.
4. Then, create another `label` element that says `Birthday: `. Set the `for` attribute of this element to `dob`.
5. After that, create an input for the user to add date. Set its `id` attribute to `dob`.
6. Add a line break.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info
files.solvedContent:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. To assign an attribute, use `attributeName = value`. 2. For line break, use `
`.

executableContent.instructions:
Before we move to the second section of the form, there's one small thing that we need to add to the first section - an update button! But why do we need an update button?

When a user will fill this section, they would need a button to update their information. Hence, we'll use `button` element to add a button.

1. Inside the `fieldset`, create a `button` after the birthday `input` that says `Update`.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info
files.solvedContent:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. Use `<button></button>` to create a button.
2. There's no need to add another line break after the button, since this `fieldset` will end and leave some space before the next `fieldset` automatically.

executableContent.instructions:
The first `fieldset` is complete and looks good! Let's move on to the second `fieldset` - `Update Password`.

For this section of the form, a user can update their password to a new one.

1. Create another HTML element inside the `form` element after the first `fieldset` element's closing tag, that groups related inputs together.
2. Create a `legend` element inside the second `fieldset` element that says `Update Password`.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info
files.solvedContent:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info


Update Password

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Refer to the code for the first `fieldset` element.

executableContent.instructions:
Just like we added labels and inputs to the first `fieldset` element, we'll add the same to this `fieldset` too.

In this one, we'll ask the user for their old password and the new password that they want to update. The reason why many sites ask for the old password before updating a new password is to confirm the user's identity and prevent hacking or stealing of accounts.

1. Below the second `legend` element, create a `label` element that says `Old password: `. Set the `for` attribute of this element to `oldpassword`.
2. After that, create an input for the user to add password. Set its `id` attribute to `oldpassword`.
3. Add a line break.
4. Then, create another `label` element that says `New password:  `. Set the `for` attribute of this element to `newpassword`.
5. After that, create an input for the user to add password. Set its `id` attribute to `newpassword`.
6. Add a line break.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info


Update Password
files.solvedContent:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info


Update Password

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. To assign an attribute, use `attributeName = value`. 2. For line break, use `
`. 3. `input` element has no closing tag.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's add another update button to this `fieldset` too!

1. Create a `button` after the new password `input` that says `Update`.

files.content:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info


Update Password

Personal Info

files.name: style.css

executableContent.instructions:
Amazing! The two sections of the form are complete!

Time for the final section - `More about you` .

Generally in social media platforms, there's always a section that takes additional information about the user so that other people viewing their profile can know more about them.

Let's go ahead and create our final `fieldset` !

1. Create another element inside the `form` element after the second `fieldset` element's closing tag that groups related inputs together.
2. Create a `legend` element inside the third `fieldset` element that says `More about you` .

files.name: index.html
files.content:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info


Update Password
files.solvedContent:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info


Update Password

More about you

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. Use `<fieldset></fieldset>` to create a `fieldset` element.
2. Use `<legend></legend>` to create a `legend` element.

lessons.title: Labels and inputs for third fieldset

executableContent.instructions:
In this section, we'll ask the user for some informal information for their profile like their pronouns, country etc.

1. Below the third `legend` element, create a `label` element that says `Pronouns: `. Set the `for` attribute of this element to `pronouns`.
2. After that, create an input for the user to add text. Set its `id` attribute to `pronouns`.
3. Add a line break.
4. Then, create another `label` element that says `Country:  `. Set the `for` attribute of this element to `country`.
5. After that, create an input for the user to add text. Set its `id` attribute to `country`.
6. Add a line break.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info


Update Password

More about you
files.solvedContent:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info


Update Password

More about you

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. To assign an attribute, use `attributeName = value`. 2. For line break, use `
`. 3. `input` element has no closing tag.

executableContent.instructions:
There's also one more piece of information that we'll ask the user for - their bio. A bio is a short profile or description of someone. This will let the user add additional information about them in their own words.

Now, for a bio, an input field with the type `text` can be very small. We'd have to adjust the size of the input field using CSS. Instead, we'll go for an easier alternative - a `textarea` element. 

`textarea` is another element used in forms that accepts multi-line text input.

1. Below the country `input`, create a `label` element that says `Bio: `. Set the `for` attribute of this element to `bio`.
2. After that, create a `textarea` element by using `<textarea></textarea>`. Set its `id` attribute to `bio`. Look at the hints for more information on `textarea` elements.
3. Add a line break.
4. Create a `button` that has the text `Update`.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info


Update Password

More about you
files.solvedContent:
friendsbook.

Update Profile Information

Personal Info


Update Password

More about you

files.name: style.css

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
1. You'll notice that the `textarea` element has both opening and closing tags, unlike an `input` element. Also, look at the output and see how `textarea` holds a bigger space compared to other input elements.

2. Use `<button></button>` to create a button.
